content.div:
The popular kids' series about an adventurous journalist named Tintin comes to the big screen under the careful direction of Steven Spielberg. Spectacular visuals highlight a very fun ride, as the king of overkill tones it down, and finds the right retro Euro pitch.

Starring: Jamie Bell, Daniel Craig, Simon Pegg and Andy Serkis

Rating: Three and a half stars out of five

Just when you thought it wasn't safe to get in a theatre with Steven Spielberg, along comes redemption in the unlikely form of a Gallic kids' literary hero.

Known to generations of schoolchildren across the globe through the illustrated books by Belgium's Herge, Tintin is a courageous, crime-solving journalist who escapes death in every adventure, thanks in large part to his dog, Snowy.

Because Tintin is pretty much asexual, and because the books are designed for boyish appeal, and because schmaltz is never a risk in an animated film, Spielberg was the perfect person to tap for the challenge of bringing Tintin to the big screen.

The shlock meister is a self-confessed kid at heart, so his skills are perfectly suited to the subject material. There may have been some doubt about the California native's ability to capture the European feel of the pages, but style is the first thing that strikes you right off the opening credits.

Every single frame has the same hues and saturation levels as the glossy inks. The cars are cute Citroens. People walk around with baguettes, and Tintin's blue sweater and khaki pants look like real garments.

There's something magical in watching a two-dimensional character from childhood suddenly achieve three dimensions. It's like watching Pinocchio frolic in the flesh.

Not that Spielberg goes for high realism. He finds a sweet blend of cartoon flatness and authentic dimension.

Tintin is played by Jamie Bell, but we're not actually watching Bell. We're watching Bell's performance captured by a computer, and then digitally transformed with the help of 3-D animators. It's the same for all the actors, including Daniel Craig, who plays the dastardly villain at the heart of Tintin's quest, Ivanovich Sakharine, as well as green-screen veteran Andy Serkis (Lord of the Rings), who plays Captain Haddock.

The actors' features are not recognizable, but the eyes are largely intact. Peer through the pixels on Sakharine, and you can spot Craig's blistering blue eyes.

All this computer-human hybridization can be creepy, and it frequently is. Check out the existential void called Polar Express. Fortunately, we're at a point where the technology is sophisticated enough to capture the essence of the human face -- providing it's not supposed to look "real."

Spielberg's real talent has always been in understanding the technological limits, and stretching them to the next degree. He did it with Bruce, the shark from Jaws, and he does it again here, with his surprisingly elegant piece of digital animation.

Every image feels slaved over, and every action scene feels real enough to spur suspense. And while you're aware the whole thing is little more than code strings and green screen, one can't help but marvel at the sets and the production design as a whole.

The visuals are so rich and retro, the movie finds entertainment value with sheer cosmetics.

The story veers off into space every once in a while, and Spielberg gets distracted by fight sequences, but the experience of watching Tintin prompts a certain giddiness for anyone who read the books, because Spielberg nails it.

He grasps the bizarre connection between Tintin and his dog. He introduces us to the alcoholic Captain Haddock with endless humour and a hint of consequence, and he offers up interesting doses of history with every new adventure.

This particular Tintin saga deals with sunken treasure and a story of pirate wars, but it's not really the story that hooks you. It's the look and the feel of the adventure that tickles the senses, much like the books themselves.

Those who worried that an important piece of their childhood might be tainted by Spielberg's manipulations needn't fret. Tintin is intact, with just the right amount of tongue in cheek, as well as tail-wagging sincerity.
